title: AB 2687
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 23152 of the Vehicle Code in California prohibits driving under the influence of alcohol. It is illegal to drive with a blood alcohol concentration of 0.08% or higher. Blood alcohol concentration is measured in grams of alcohol per 100 milliliters of blood or grams of alcohol per 210 liters of breath. In California, it is illegal to drive with a blood alcohol concentration of 0.08% or higher. If a person had 0.08% or more alcohol in their blood within three hours of driving, it is presumed they were over the limit. Additionally, it is unlawful for a person addicted to drugs to drive, except if they are in an approved narcotic treatment program. It is illegal to drive a commercial motor vehicle in California with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood. If a chemical test within three hours after driving shows 0.04% or more alcohol, it is presumed the person was over the limit. Starting July 1, 2018, it is illegal to drive a motor vehicle in California with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood when a passenger for hire is present. A passenger for hire is defined as someone who pays or is expected to pay for the ride. If caught, there is a presumption that the driver had 0.04% or more alcohol in their blood at the time of driving. The law in California states that if a person is found to have 0.04% or more alcohol in their blood within three hours of driving, it is presumed that they had the same amount at the time of driving. It is illegal to drive under the influence of drugs or a combination of alcohol and drugs in California. The Vehicle Code prohibits driving under the influence of alcohol, leading to bodily injury to others. It is unlawful to drive with 0.08 percent or more of alcohol in the blood and cause bodily injury to another person. There is a rebuttable presumption if a chemical test within three hours after driving shows 0.08 percent or more alcohol in the blood. In proving negligence in driving, it is not necessary to show a specific violation of the law. It is illegal to drive a commercial vehicle with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood, causing bodily injury to others. Presumption of alcohol level if tested within three hours of driving. Starting July 1, 2018, it is illegal to drive with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood if a passenger for hire is in the vehicle and causes bodily injury to someone else. A passenger for hire is someone who pays or is expected to pay for the ride. It is illegal to drive with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood if a passenger for hire is in the vehicle. In a prosecution, it is presumed that the person had 0.04% or more alcohol in their blood at the time of driving if a chemical test within three hours after driving shows the same. It is unlawful to drive under the influence of any drug or a combination of alcohol and drugs, leading to bodily injury to another person. The act does not require reimbursement under the California Constitution as it pertains to creating, eliminating, or changing penalties for crimes or infractions.
